statement: The median of an array b_1, b_2, ... b_m, written as \operatorname{med}(b_1, b_2, ..., b_m), is the â‰¤ft\lceil \frac{m}{2} \right\rceil-th^{\text{âˆ—}} smallest element of array b.You are given an array of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n and an integer k. You need to determine whether there exists a pair of indices 1 â‰¤ l < r < n such that:\operatorname{med}(\operatorname{med}(a_1, a_2, ..., a_l), \operatorname{med}(a_{l+1}, a_{l+2}, ..., a_r), \operatorname{med}(a_{r+1}, a_{r+2}, ..., a_n)) â‰¤ k.In other words, determine whether it is possible to split the array into three contiguous subarrays^{\text{â€ }} such that the median of the three subarray medians is less than or equal to k.^{\text{âˆ—}}\lceil x \rceil is the ceiling function which returns the least integer greater than or equal to x.^{\text{â€ }}An array x is a subarray of an array y if x can be obtained from y by the deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the beginning and several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the end.
input_specification: InputEach test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 â‰¤ t â‰¤ 10^4). The description of the test cases follows. The first line of each test case contains two integers n and k (3 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 2 Â· 10^5, 1 â‰¤ k â‰¤ 10^9)Â â€” the length of the array a and the constant k.The second line of each test case contains n integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (1 â‰¤ a_i â‰¤ 10^9)Â â€” the elements of the array a.It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 2 Â· 10^5.
output_specification: OutputFor each testcase, output "YES" if such a split exists, and "NO" otherwise.You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
